Fields.DialogueText: Thank you all for coming today. If there are no burning questions, let us begin the briefing.
Sure, but try to make it quick.
Ready when you are!
Yep, I'm all ears.
I'm itching to get started!
To business, then. As you know, we'll be putting on a performance for the crew as thanks for all their hard work.
It's been decided that a performance of The Nutcracker would be the most appropriate, given the season.
You're in charge? I don't remember having that vote.
No further questions? Khorosho.
... As is to be expected. I'll briefly explain the plot for those of you who have yet to view this masterpiece.
On Christmas Eve, a family invites a magician to perform for their children. The magician completes his act and gifts the young ones with a small nutcracker doll.
As night falls, the room morphs into a battlefield between gingerbread soldiers and an army of rats. The Nutcracker springs to life in order to protect the children and emerges triumphant!
The young girl, Clara, now saved by the Nutcracker, is taken to the Land of Sweets and introduced to the Sugar Plum Fairy - the ballerina of her dreams.
The story then concludes with Clara waking up at the foot of her tree on Christmas morning.
Do you understand?
There's going to be a war? I'm sold.
Seconded.
Aside from pressing children into a war with a rat infestation, the story sounds lovely.
Perfect! In that case, I'll be assigning the roles. Achilles, you'll be playing the Nutcracker.
Ha! Of course I'd be the main character. Good call, Moskva.
Minneapolis, you'll be the Mouse King - the character who wages war against the gingerbread men.
But gingerbread men are my specialty!
Then that saves you some reconnaissance. Fubuki, you will be the Snow Queen.
What a surprise...
Antoniotto will make for a fine Harlequin Doll.
A doll? As in, a non-speaking doll? How do you expect me to steal the show in such a role?
I don't.
Full creative control? Interesting...
Maillé Brézé will be Clara, the young girl who sets off on the magical adventure.
In what world do I look like a helpless little girl to you?
The world in which we need a Clara who can be easily lifted. Besides, I thought you'd jump at the chance to be the protagonist.
She's the main character? Why didn't you just say so?!
Hey, I thought I was the main character!
Are your ears broken? You heard Moskva, didn't you?
Comrades, please. I think everyone here knows who the "real" main character is.
Of course I wouldn't.
Of course *I* wouldn't.
Then we're agreed. No further questions?
What about your role, Moskva?
Me? Well, the only role left is the Sugar Plum Fairy.
You?! That's got to be the greatest miscast in history, no?
Who died and made you prima ballerina?
When I hear the name "Moskva," it certainly does not evoke feelings of warmth and whimsy.
Now, now, I think Moskva will do just fine as the Sugar Plum Fairy. She knows her Russian ballet.
You might say it's in my blood. Now, we'll have only a short while to ready everything necessary for the performance, so I trust you'll follow my direction to the letter.
Anyway. Hans is a perfect fit for Drosselmeyer, the magician and toymaker.
These hands are pretty magical, all things considered. You've seen the things I can do with a wrench.
What shall we do first?

Fields.MenuText: Moskva: Learning your choreography will be of the utmost importance.

Fields.DialogueText: That shouldn't be a problem. If I can remember the skeleton of an internal combustion engine, a few lines and dance moves shouldn't be an issue!

Fields.MenuText: Moskva: We'll need as many props and as much equipment as we can muster to pull this off. Who wants to tug on the Captain's heartstrings?

Fields.DialogueText: Leave it to me. I think I know the Captain best when it comes to wrangling promises.
If there are no further questions, feel free to enjoy the rest of your day. I'll drop the scripts by your quarters later this evening.
Rehearsals begin first thing in the morning. From then, welcome to the immediate focus of your lives.
Let's go, team!
This should be fun!
I can't wait for that war scene!
Make sure you all get enough sleep tonight. Don't spend too long reading your lines.
I'm ready for a spectacular performance!
Fubuki? Is something wrong?
No... Maybe...
It's just... A tireless enemy lies just beyond the horizon.
The Rusalki.
Hai. They will not become passive just because it is Christmas. Chotto shinpaishimasu.
We are all worried, Fubuki. That does not mean we should let the Rusalki control our lives.
So we should remain vigilant and less... less.... frolicking. Chigaimasuka?
Don't think of this as a vacation. Think of this as a reward for the crew who give so much of themselves to our cause on a daily basis.
Moskva...
The First Comrades don't need a break, but the crew do. There's no telling when they can go home or on leave in such a time of crisis.
The least we can do is lift their spirits however possible.
And if doing so can be a little fun for us as well, what's the harm?
Naruhodo. Tasshikani, if it is to keep the morale of the crew in top condition, then we have an obligation to put on the best performance possible.
That's the spirit.
The Christmas spirit.
The alternative is death.
And a toymaker, you say? Hmm...
Sorry I'm late. Miyuki and I got to talking.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Captain? Captain!
What? Who's--
Oh. Sorry, Achilles. I must have dozed off.
I haven't seen you sleep since at least last week.
And when would you have seen the Capitaine sleep?
Aren't you on shift to bother someone else?
I was sent to find you! You're on watch in five minutes!
Calm down, both of you. Your roles are equally important. And you've got plenty of time until opening night.
Swapped with Kersaint. You hadn't heard?
You can't just do that! You're a completely different ship class!
I've got eyes same as her, haven't I? Anyway, if you ask me, you Vauquelins could learn a thing or two from us Leanders.
Like how to be an arrogant shirker?
Opening night? What are you talking about, Capitaine?
... Maybe I ought to let you sleep.
Consider it practice for minding your business.
You're not on watch for the mouse king? Under the tree and... the mice...?
Hey! I have a free shift to make you eat those words!
... First things first. I'm putting in for an emergency coffee ration.
Present! Let's get building.
But I digress. I have the most experience with ballet.... So I will be your rezhisser- ah, director.
No vote is necessary. I'm the most qualified. So, according to my ability, I lead and you follow.
Who here is already familiar with the general plot of the Nutcracker?
"No further questions", my eye...
We'll talk about that privately. Tak ili inache...
But--
But if you must *borrow* the limelight, there will be an opportunity for you to perform a small dance number. You can even choreograph it, if you must.
There is no room for *ego* upon my stage. You steal from your fellow performers, you will regret it.
If it helps you to see it in that light....
Do you really want to lose your dignity-- or your leading role-- over a petty disagreement?
I lived and made myself one. If you're unhappy with that, feel free to walk away.
Make it so, then.
Your enthusiasm is admirable. Your technique is not.
Ballet is not frolicking. This is as serious as any mission.
We've adapted the ballet to be a little more enjoyable for our sailors. The dances will be separated by scenes with speaking parts.
Which, for the record, is a terrible idea.
Oh, come on. We talked about this already. There's plenty of sailors from cultures that don't know the Nutcracker-
I am *painfully aware* of this.
-- And they deserve to know what's going on too, don'tcha know.
They'd know what's going on better without spoken lines. Dance is an art form that transcends language.
(Bah. I still can't believe I agreed to let them add speaking parts.... it's a travesty.)
Okay, everyone, file in, please.
Time to eat already?
I'm afraid not. I leaned on the galley staff to lend us this space for our rehearsals and performance.
The mess hall? Not the deck?
The weather won't allow it. This is the only space large enough to fit an entire audience alongside our backstage.
It's perfect! The smell of the fryer, the roar of the peeling paint! I can't wait for my show-stopping dance number!
Show-stopping... Antoniotto, your dance number opens the performance.
Yes, about that. I was looking over the script and I think we should be allowed to take a few liberties.
Is that so?
Yes, well, you *did* say I could make my part my own. So, I've choreographed a teeny-tiny show-stopper where I come back during the climax. It's the work of no more than... oh, I'd say an hour.
Absolutely not. I agreed to let you alter your individual scene, not to --
Hey, if Antoniotto is allowed to have all that, I don't see why you are so opposed to me designing some gingerbread robots for my scene.
As I told you, we have neither the time nor the budget to-- Bah! You two, what are you bickering about?
Moskva, could you please talk some sense into this Belle? I fear she has gone off the rails.
I don't see what's so crazy about using some of the crew for the war scene. What kind of battle is it between only a handful of people?!
Perhaps one or two--
No, no, no, I would need more like fifty.
Fifty?!
Is this a war or a picnic?!
We're not choreographing fifty extras! Or can't you count!?
Maillé Brézé, let's not--
They'd distract from my performance as the lead!
You're distracted from the truth... I'm the lead!
Minneapolis, I need some good news. There are no problems on your end, da?
Me? I'm perfectly fine and ready to get to work.
There. Do the rest of you see? That is the attitude that I-
I've just made one quick change here. Instead of instigating a war, the Mouse King now distributes rations to all the children! Isn't that wonderful?
The Mouse King.
I understand, but I feel a little uncomfortable sending all the mice into battle on my behalf. They have the numbers, but they're criminally outgunned.
I doubt the Mouse King was such a compassionate leader.
Could we not devise some kind of union for these mice? Then they could voice their objections and opt out of such needless bloodshed if necessary.
The script is not open to rewrites.
That's... what do you commies call it... Revolutionary defeatism!
That's not what I-- Wait a minute, where is Fubuki?
I believe she's in the corner rehearsing her lines.
Da, da, da. Fubuki, could you come here?
Is there a problem?
Your rehearsal. How is it going?
As per your suggestion, Moskva-san.
Finally, someone taking this seriously! Khorosho. Show me what you've got.
Now-then-Clara-please-board-this-sleigh-with-your-handsome-prince-and-set-off-on-your-journey-into-the-land-of-sweets-you-will-be-welcomed-by-emissaries-from-all-over-the-world.
Do you know how commas work, Fubuki?
Pauses for breath. Do fairies breathe?
... Keep practicing. You've learnt your lines. Learn them with feeling.
Hai, Moskva-san.
Moskva! Come and settle this argument!
Moskva, tell this brute that the story doesn't revolve around her! It revolves around me!
Moskva, darling! I have those rewrites ready!
Moskva, I'm just dipping out to fetch some oil. I'll have those puppets moving by themselves in no time!
Moskva! How would you feel if I added some singing to my big dance number?
Moskva-san-do-you-think-this-is-better-this-is-me-trying-to-speak-in-the-same-tone-I-would-during-the-grand-finale.
Moskva!
Moskva!
Moskva!
Moskva!
Moskva-san.
Moskva~~~~~!
I should have you all flogged for this! You're a disgrace to the Ballets Russe, to Anna Pavlova, and to Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky himself!
No need to shout.
Ja, we're just trying to get things right.
I won't be shouted at by a supporting character, you know.

Fields.MenuText: Moskva: I... apologize. That was disproportionate.

Fields.DialogueText: You startled us, Moskva. Are you feeling okay now?

Fields.MenuText: Moskva: Stop. Talking.  All of you.

Fields.DialogueText: What about singing~?

Fields.MenuText: Moskva: Directing you is like squeezing blood from a stone.

Fields.DialogueText: Then make us bleed! Show us what you've got!
In the interest of keeping you on board, I've tried to listen to your suggestions. For better or for worse.
And?
We should rehearse, with what we've got. All of it. Start to end.
With the war scene?
Yes.
And the puppetry?
Sure.
And my musical number?
Why not?
After all, how bad could it be?
Bozhe moi.
Might explain the burned bacon this morning.
Famously the villain.
Who else?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
And don't even get me started on this skirt. Pine needles? I'll go up in flames the minute a spotlight comes near me!
Fräulein Fubuki. You're up late.
Konbanwa, Hannah-san. What's your excuse?
Midnight snack. I've been having a terrible time trying to make my mines self-propelling, and--
Since at least the start of middle watch.
How long have *you* been watching?
You don't think it's Sloth's doing?
... How long has the Kapitän been sleeping there?
Ja, dumb question. I wouldn't worry. It's been a busy December.
Since at least the--
Nein, nein, just exhaustion. I took the liberty of upgrading the Kapitän's alarm clock in the meantime.
Should I be concerned?
It ought to go off in a week. A lot louder, granted, but it's a first draft.
It was the strangest thing. Kanchou was muttering about fairies and mice...
So that's what Maillé Brézé was talking about. I thought she was just being impertinent.
Well, mines don't automate themselves. I'll leave you to it.
Hai.
... How long are you planning on watching?
I'm waiting for Kanchou to start muttering again. I was really starting to get invested.
Because, if we really want to make the pigeon puppets come alive-
We *absolutely* do.
I have some ideas.
She has some ideas, Moskva.

Fields.MenuText: Moskva: Da, da. We'll get you whatever you need.

Fields.DialogueText: Sehr gut!
If you two don't stop bickering I will put you under *every spotlight we possess* right now.
And yes, that is a threat.
There's no reason to overcomplicate this. For the Revolution's sake--
Splendid! I'll get to work on a couple of rewrites.
Have you tapped into your character's true emotions yet?
Hai. They look different in Russian, but-
That was staccato. Emotionless. Wooden!
I can see your effort. I know you are trying. But show me results.
ZAMOLCHI!
Arrêtez! Shut UP!
I intend to.
I am. I was before.
Bad. And that is the point.
Huh?
As I expected. I let each of you make your own choices, and I was not disappointed, because...
This is the worst rendition of The Nutcracker I have ever witnessed in my entire life!
Maillé Brézé and Achilles, if I catch you at each other's throats one more time, you'll hang by them!
Minneapolis - the politics of a world of fictional mice are none of your concern!
Antoniotto, this isn't a Bolshoi production. We haven't the time or the space for your dance numbers!
Hans, your robots are out of control! They're a threat to the audience and your fellow performers!
And Fubuki somehow manages to express less emotion than Hans' machines!
We have done things your way. And it was an unmitigated disaster.
I never wanted to do The Nutcracker anyway. You were the one who talked the Captain's ear off about it.
Indeed. I think some kind of cabaret would be far more exhilarating.
Could we not have some kind of awards ceremony instead? If this is all for the sake of the crew, we should honor their efforts directly.
Moskva, we haven't even seen you perform yet. Show us what "your way" looks like.
Me...? Very well...
Let me just... find my bearings... --AH!
*THUD*
What was that?!
You could barely stay on one leg for half a second!
Hm... Maybe it would be better if you worried about your own performance before being so quick to judge ours.
Don't think I won't train! Don't think I won't be ready! I have a vision I mean to see realized!
... For the war scene?
For the crew!
If I had my way, we'd be doing a very different production. But I have a vision. I want to try and make this a night the crew will never forget!
Franchement, I couldn't forget that display if I tried.
And I suppose you just fell into the role of the Sugar Plum Fairy by accident.
I manifested as a ballerina. That doesn't mean I don't have to practice, but it gives me a head start. Something to aspire to.
But I didn't take on this role to live out some girlish dream.
Then why?
Because I know in my heart of hearts... that I will give the performance of my life in service to the crew who dreamed this hopeful ballerina into their world.
*Sniff* *Sniff*
Achilles, are you crying?
What are you talking about?! Stop looking at me when you should be paying attention to Moskva!
*Now* you say it.
*ALARM*
Morganas!
Who else?!
It seems Christmas is not a time of rest in a world of monsters!
Vile brutes! They must have caught wind of our performance and want to put a stop to it!
I'm not sure if that's quite the reason, but it doesn't change things.
Right! Come on, ladies! Let's send these Morganas back where they came from! Are you ready, Moskva?
... Ochen' khorosho. Let me show you all how it's done.
@BATTLE
Good job out there, all of you. You performed magnificently.
Ha! It was nothing. None of us suffered so much as a scratch.
Moskva's right. Everyone did their best.
After such a successful battle, I'm struggling to remember any of the issues we had.
Fubuki's right. I can't understand why I decided to die on this hill of robots.
And what were we arguing about, Achilles?
Beats me. All of my attention was focused on watching you during that last fight. You were incredible!
Likewise! You slay Morganas like you were built to.
As for me, I don't think I have the energy left to stand... never mind perform an entire dance number.
I would like to apologize for the way I spoke to you all earlier. It was... Unprofessional.
I think we could all do with a round of apologies, Moskva.

Fields.MenuText: Moskva: Who'd like to go first?

Fields.DialogueText: I was speaking mainly metaphorically...

Fields.MenuText: Moskva: ... I promise you, your mice will be taken care of.

Fields.DialogueText: That's all I needed to hear!
We don't have much time left before the deadline.
We haven't even started on the costumes. And the choreography is ... I've simplified it as much as I can, but it's...
Then we'll just have to all work twice as hard to make this the best show ever!
Right! Achilles and Maillé Brézé, can you two run through lines with Fubuki?
Us?
You two are passionate and charismatic. Fubuki could learn a lot from you.
Got it!
Yoroshiku onegaishimasu.
Minneapolis, can you and Hans work together on some of the costumes? I'm sure with Hans' design skills and your work ethic, the two of you can do wonders!
Leave it to us! Textile engineering's not my strong suit, but I can do set design and--
We've got this! I'll ring up Henley, see if she can give us a tip or two.
Speaking of tips. Antoniotto... do you think you could give me some pointers about my dance number?
I would be honored! Come, come, there's no time to waste! The way I'd recommend you start is--
Oh, everyone!
One last thing before we begin...
I just wanted to say...
From the bottom of my heart...
Ugh! I'm sick of this sentimental crap! Can we just get to work already?!
Da. I'll save it for the afterparty!
Let's get started!
Aye-aye!
... You didn't mean that in a sinister way, did you?
(I've practiced... haven't I? Bozhe moi, why can't I remember anything?)
... Ugh. How long was I out?
Oh, Capitano! Would you like to get in on the pool?
What pool? Have you been talking to Edinburgh?
No, silly. Fubuki's off on reconnaissance, so nobody really knows how long you've been asleep.
Sooo... I thought I'd make a little game of it. Make hay before the Capitano rises and shines, as it were.
Cheating our sailors out of their wages, pevitsa?
Oh, don't be so grim. My commission's going straight to the fleet's Christmas dinner.
Moskva! Thank goodness you're here. Maybe you can make sense of all this.
I certainly hope so. We've got to get you on a regular sleeping schedule.
No, no. I've been having the same dream for days. You're there, and Antoniotto, Minneapolis - there's seven of you, and you're putting on a ballet - well, not a ballet, per se, but--
A recurring dream?
Right.
A dream that you've been having.
Was that not clear?
Kapitan, I pride myself on doing the impossible in your service. But how do you expect me to answer for something that takes place entirely in your own head?
... Well, I--
Well, when you put it that way it just sounds idiotic.
Not helping.
... So, I'll put you down for a maybe, then? Nobody's guessed six hours yet.
If you're looking for something to do, pevitsa, I need a spotter for my gunnery routine. There's this pirouette that I just can't seem to sync up with my anti-air.
Ah! Perhaps what you need is the proper accompaniment. Now, I'm no coloratura, but...
It's got to be the coffee. It's just got to be.
*sigh*
And maybe a little more concern for the well-being of the mice.
No. My word is my bond.
So now we do them my way. Or we do not do them at all.
I'll... perform a short snippet from the Dance of the Sugar-Plum Fairy. Of course.
My ankle. I'm fine.
You're quick to judge, yourself!
*MURMUR* *MUTTER* *CHATTER*
Five to places, everyone!
Achilles! Get to your starting position!
Fubuki! Your smile needs to be wider!
And can someone PLEASE tell Hans that if she gets a drop of oil on any of these dresses, there will be hell to pay!
Good call, Moskva. Antoniotto was certainly the right person to put in charge.
Behind every good director is a good stage manager.
Are you nervous at all? The mess hall is completely packed.
Maybe a little. But for all I know, it could just be pure anticipation. I keep waiting for the other shoe to drop, as you Americans put it.
All the more reason to keep our feet planted.
There's no way to keep your feet planted en jeté.
Okay, Act I is just about to start! It's time for Moskva's speech!
My what?!
Oh, porco-- whose job was it to tell Moskva about her speech?!
Ah, tut mir leid!
What are you all talking about?
We were all so moved by your speech the other day.
Yeah, it really got us fired up!
So we decided as a group that you should give a short introduction to the audience.
As a way to get them excited for the show.
But I haven't prepared any--
And you're on in three, two--
Wait!
Go get 'em!
*MUTTER* *MUTTER* SHHHHHHH!
... Dobryy vecher.
*Cough*
Today, we'll be performing our rendition of the Nutcracker for you all.
Today is a day for elation.
You have all put in a lot of effort to aid us in this war, and we would like to reward your generosity with a moment's respite.
I think that's all I had to say. Thank you very much for listening.
CLAP!
*ROARING APPLAUSE*
Ladies and gentlemen.
Sit back.
Relax.
And enjoy a performance like you've never seen before!
*ONE ACT LATER*
Thank you, everyone! Feel free to take a short break and we'll be right back for the second half!
Things are going great so far!
Right! They love us!
Good job, everyone!
Don't lose focus now. A gymnast's routine isn't complete until they stick the landing.
I'm not worried.
What about you, Moskva?
That's right. It's nearly time for your big debut.
Right. Antoniotto's stage management has given me plenty of time to practice.
You'll be great, Moskva.
Don't worry. We'll be there to catch you if you fall down.
We've come this far. This is no time to get cold feet...
If you've put me through all this just to walk out before the curtain falls...!
We all believe in you, Moskva. Make sure you believe in yourself too.
Agreed!
You're the best comrades a girl could ask for. Come on, it's time for the second half!
*ONE ACT LATER*
*APPLAUSE*
Fubuki as the Snow Queen!
I hope I stirred... passion within you all.
Hans as Drosselmeyer!
Was my performance as magical as I thought it was?
Maillé Brézé as Clara!
Never underestimate a little girl. At least when she's backed by a magician!
Minneapolis as the Mouse King!
Please don't take this performance to heart, everyone! You have no need to worry about stricter working conditions on my watch!
Achilles as the Nutcracker!
And don't you forget it!
Myself as the Harlequin Doll. I would be happy to perform an encore for anyone interested!
And, last but not least, Moskva.
Without her guidance, leadership, and passion, none of this would have been possible.
Give it up one more time for the Belle of the hour!
*APPLAUSE*

Fields.MenuText: Moskva: Spasibo ot vsego serdtsa i dushi. Thank you from my heart.
Moskva: I couldn't have done this without the rest of the Belles. They're the true stars.

Fields.DialogueText: This isn't a concert, you know?
As humble as ever!

Fields.MenuText: Moskva: We'll be collecting tips from now until curfew!

Fields.DialogueText: Wasn't this supposed to be a free performance?
It seems the fame may have gone to her head.
This was truly magical. Spasibo-- Spasibo-- Spasi-
*ALARM*
What the...?
Oh, Captain, thank goodness you're awake. I was worried you'd toss and turn right into your meatloaf.
The place is deserted. Was I sleeping?
Like a log. Our Christmas morale officer thought we should just leave you be.
Yes, I suppose I was.
Yes. Please. I'd better get to a real bed in the meantime. Thanks for running interference.
Not a problem. Oh, and thank you for the nutcracker.
The what?!
The... nutcracker? You lent it to me so I could finish my packet of pistachios.
Ah, right.
Ope, watch where you step! Looks like I missed a few pine needles there. Let me just hunt down that broom...
Wait, Minneapolis, what did you just say?! Wait! Come back here!
Thank you, five!
Thank you, everyone! Now that the smoke has cleared...
I *told* her this skirt was too flammable.
Let's give it up one more time for the Bellissimi Fantasmi who made this all possible!
Thanks. Wouldn't do to have pine needles all over...
Grr... Latecomers will not be seated!
@BATTLE
I did my best to keep the other Belles from bothering you. We know you've been busy.
Want me to wrap up that meatloaf for you?
... Our Christmas morale officer?
You looked like you were having a lovely dream.
You know, Mr. Lugin's business connection.
The smuggler we picked up at the last stop? The one with the misspelled "Muther" tattoo?
That's him! Since he was in an elf suit anyway, he volunteered to help bring joy and goodwill around the ship.
He was hoping he could stay on, actually. Apparently it would be problematic to go back home for a while.

Fields.MenuText: ... We'll find somewhere safe to drop him off. Immediately.

Fields.DialogueText: That's the spirit!
Ho ho ho.
Okay, Captain.
So...
True. I guess... we rise, we fall, we try again.
For the next few hours, put aside your duties, your responsibilities, and your cares. Let the performance bring you joy.
I hope you enjoy the show as much as we enjoyed rehearsing it.
So far, no major mistakes. Let's hope we can keep this up.

Fields.Title: Conversation 4
Fields.Description: Note: Don't forget to put your costumes on for the play!
